options.label: Gender stereotypes and roles are influenced by many factors
There are many reasons why gender equality is difficult to achieve at work and at home
Governments need to do more to encourage gender equality in domestic roles
Fathers need to spend more time in the home and sharing domestic tasks

data.stimulus:
Quick Reading

► Read the text quickly. 

► You should spend about 5 minutes reading the text and answering the questions.

 

 

Focus on the topic sentence of each section and read the rest of the section quickly. 

(don't stop to check vocabulary -- you can do this in the next activity).

 

► Which statement that summarises the writer's point of view?

value: Equality in parenting is necessary for full gender equality
When fathers want to be more involved in childcare, they find it difficult to negotiate flexible working hours in the workplace
There not enough father-friendly policies, fathers don't want to use them, there is no financial support long-term

possible_responses: There not enough father-friendly policies, fathers don't want to use them, there is no financial support long-term
When fathers want to be more involved in childcare, they find it difficult to negotiate flexible working hours in the workplace
Equality in parenting is necessary for full gender equality

value: Equality in parenting is necessary for full gender equality
When fathers want to be more involved in childcare, they find it difficult to negotiate flexible working hours in the workplace
There not enough father-friendly policies, fathers don't want to use them, there is no financial support long-term
An alternative approach to parental leave
Germany's family-friendly policy offer fathers more money and for a longer time
However, it has been criticised for being an expensive policy.
Father-friendly policies bring benefits to all family members

Father-friendly policies create better family relationships (fathers spend more time with children/stable families), better child development (more parental time) and better work-life balance for women

data.stimulus: To finish your study of this text, complete the summary with words from the drop down.
data.template: According to research carried out for the Economic and Social Research Council (2010), in order for full {{response}} to be possible in the workplace and at home, it is necessary to consider how {{response}} roles can be made more equal. There are currently several obstacles to this. Firstly, fathers may find it difficult to deal with {{response}}: the majority of primary carers are mothers and employers may not consider making the necessary {{response}} for men to look after children. Secondly, the current UK {{response}}, designed to allow fathers to participate more in childcare, are {{response}} both in terms of how much financial support is offered and how long this support is offered for.

On the other hand, some countries, such as Germany, offer more support and similar {{response}} could be adopted in Britain, although the cost of this to {{response}} needs to be considered. Overall, it is worth developing policies to {{response}} more equality in parenting, as this benefits the whole family, allowing a better quality of {{response}}, stronger family {{response}}, and a greater opportunity for equality in the workplace due to a fairer distribution of the {{response}} at home.

 

Reference:
Economic and Social Research Council (2010), 'Helping fathers stay at home is key to equality', Britain in 2010, 102-103

data.template:
• 1. A famous person should be aware of how they behave because they are often seen as a {{response}} by young fans.
  • 2. No-one believed she could be a good car mechanic because she was a woman. This kind of {{response}} meant it was difficult for her to find a job.
  • 3. He wanted more money but because of his lack of {{response}} he was afraid to ask for pay rise.
  • 4. Staff {{response}} is terrible in this school. Half of the teachers leave at the end of each year.
  • 5. Going to the party had an {{response}} effect on her performance in the exam the following day.
  • 6. Christie has been an excellent {{response}} since I started in the company. She's always available when I have questions and we meet regularly to discuss my progress.

• 7. The research council awarded a generous {{response}} to support my work in sustainable materials development.
  • 8. The sports club tries to be as {{response}} as possible. It is offers facilities and special offers to encourage membership from the whole community.
  • 9. Sometimes {{response}} can feel very different from the corporate world. For this reason, we make sure that we maintain strong links with local businesses on this course.
  • 10. People presume that all men love sport but that's just {{response}}. None of the men in my family are particularly interested in it.

options.label: For women to succeed in academia, they need to work harder
For women to succeed in academia, they need a more flexible workplace
For women to succeed in academia, they need more positive examples

data.stimulus:
In this task, you will read the text quickly to get a general understanding of the content.

► Spend about 5 minutes reading the text.

 

 

 

Focus on the topic sentence of each section and read the rest of the section quickly. 

(don't stop to check vocabulary -- you can do this in the next activity).

 

► Which statement that summarises the writer's point of view?

value: It more difficult for women to find out about opportunities for research and career progression in academia because men dominate information networks
Women have to work harder than men if they want to succeed in academia
Girls first learn to believe in stereotypes about what they can and cannot do at home and at school
Stereotyping causes women to lose confidence in their abilities from when they are children
Caring responsibilities and childcare are elements of traditional domestic roles which can prevent women from progressing in academic careers

possible_responses: Girls first learn to believe in stereotypes about what they can and cannot do at home and at school
Stereotyping causes women to lose confidence in their abilities from when they are children
It more difficult for women to find out about opportunities for research and career progression in academia because men dominate information networks
Caring responsibilities and childcare are elements of traditional domestic roles which can prevent women from progressing in academic careers
Women have to work harder than men if they want to succeed in academia

value: Changes in the workplace have not helped enough with women's career progression

data.stimulus: To finish your study of this text, complete the summary with words from the drop down.
data.template:
The article describes various {{response}} that make it more difficult for women to {{response}} in academic institutions. It argues that women have to work harder and longer to {{response}} the same level of success as men. It also claims that women's self-image, behaviour and academic choices are {{response}} by their own belief in gender {{response}}. Therefore, the solution proposed in the article is not to provide more flexible working {{response}}, as this does not help women to {{response}} in their careers. Instead, it suggests focusing on examples of successful female {{response}} and how their success was achieved, as this will encourage more women to aim for more {{response}} academic roles. 

 

Reference:

Economic and Social Research Council (2010), 'Still hitting the ceiling', Society Now, 6, 10
